This is a passage from a book called Radical Honesty by Brad Blanton:
 
 "We all lie like hell. It wears us out. It is the major source of all human stress. Lying kills people. Psychological illness of the severest kind is the result of this kind of lying. Psychological healing is possible only with the freedom that comes from not hiding anymore....
 ....Withholding from other people, not telling them about what we feel or think, keeps us locked in the jail. The longer we remain in that jail, the quicker we decline. We either escape, or we go dead. The way out is to get good at telling the truth."

 The origin of lying is our upbringing. We learn to lie and pretend in the early childhood, because we learn that when we do something 'wrong' (= not consistent with what others expect us from to do or it is not within the social norms) we we'll avoid punishment, if we don't admit to what we supposedly have done 'wrong', or some other unpleasant consequance or to accuire some form of reward. It is our natural tendency to feel as good as we can as much as we can. And in order to get it we develop strategies to accuire it. Lying is just one among of them.
